title: OVERPROMPT processes multiple items per session (should be 1)
resolution_notes: Updated both OVERPROMPT-standard.md and OVERPROMPT-gitops.md to enforce single-item processing per session. Changed session limits from 5 to 1, updated Phase 7 logic to exit after completion instead of looping, updated execution flow diagrams, and modified safeguards/exit conditions. Changes committed in cc88733.
description: OVERPROMPT.md currently allows 'max 5 items per session' but this is problematic. Without specialized agents, manual execution of 5 items is risky. It creates large, hard-to-review git commits, violates single-responsibility principle, and makes rollback difficult. The loop should exit after exactly 1 iteration, not 5.
steps_to_reproduce: Execute OVERPROMPT workflow with multiple queued items
Observe it attempts to process up to 5 items in one session
expected_behavior: OVERPROMPT should process exactly 1 item per session, then exit to retrospective and summary reporting. This ensures focused commits, easier review, and safer rollback.
actual_behavior: OVERPROMPT allows up to 5 items per session, leading to large mixed commits and increased error risk.

evidence.workflow_loop: Phase 7 logic allows iteration up to 5 times

root_cause: Template was designed with batch processing in mind, but practical experience shows single-item sessions are safer and more maintainable. This should be enforced, not configurable.
impact: Medium severity - doesn't break functionality but creates operational risk. Large batch commits are harder to review, debug, and rollback. Error in item 3 of 5 means items 1-2 might need to be reverted too.
